data: Social Innovation in Marginalised Rural Areas

SIMRA seeks to advance understanding of social innovation (SI) and innovative governance in agriculture, forestry and rural development (RD), and how to boost them, particularly in marginalised rural areas across Europe, with a focus on the Mediterranean region (including non-EU) where there is limited evidence of outcomes and supporting conditions. These objectives will be achieved by: 
1. Developing systematic frameworks: a) theoretical - for improved knowledge of the complexity of SIs and its dimensions, and its impact on unfolding territorial capital; b) operational - based on a trans-disciplinary coalition (researchers and practitioners) to advance understanding of preconditions and success factors (e.g. instruments, incentives etc.) for implementing/operationalizing SI. 
2. Creating a categorisation of SIs which encompasses the specificities in terms of social priorities, relationships/collaborations etc. and serves as an instrument to explore reasons why regions with similar conditions display diverging paths and to 'turn diversity into strength’.
3. Creating an integrated set of methods to evaluate SI and its impacts on economic, social, environmental, institutional and policy dimensions of territorial capital.
4.  Co-constructed evaluation of SIs in case studies across the spatial variation of European rural areas, considering which components of territorial capital foster and, or mainstream RD. 
5. Synthesis and dissemination of new or improved knowledge of SIs and novel governance mechanisms to promote social capital and institutional capacity building and inform effective options/solutions for shaping sustainable development trajectories. 
6. Creating collaborative learning and networking opportunities and launching innovative actions at different/multiple scales, with continuous interactions among researchers, ‘knowledge brokers’ and stakeholders to foster and mainstream SI, leaving a durable legacy.

The French training project ( The French immersion courses) created by LFEE will give the participants an opportunity to develop their language teaching skills, improve their language knowledge and abilities and deepen their understanding of other cultures. These are essential skills to successfully deliver the recommendations of the L1+2 Modern Language policy that is being implemented in Angus schools. All knowledge and skills gained will enhance the learning experience of Isla pupils and staff as well as raise awareness of the importance of Modern Languages in the field of potential future employment.
The objectives are to improve the confidence and competence of the participants in order that they can take forward and support the L1+2 initiative across the staff team at Isla and with cluster colleagues. 
• To improve and enhance conversational French and to gain new ideas for the classroom.
• To develop and maintain a bank of resources to use within the school  ICT/Internet, books, songs and films.
• To develop cultural awareness and an understanding of modern day living in France.
• To improve pedagogy.

This application is for two members of staff. Isla is a small rural school so it is our intention that the applicants will cascade knowledge gained to other staff and will take both take lead roles in the development of language skills and knowledge within the school and associated cluster schools when the opportunity arises. One participant as the school’s French Coordinator for Isla will work with the Head Teacher to direct the development of the school aims. 
The week long French immersion courses will provide daily opportunities to gain further skills in Languages and cultural knowledge through studies of a range of pedagogical techniques. It will provide experiences as both teacher and pupil and complete immersion in the language and culture through visits to planned sites. All of these will greatly improve the participants’ individual skills in the effectiveness of teaching a modern language.

The intensive week long professional learning experience will provide the practical/interactive model of how to teach a modern foreign language effectively. It would be expected that the participants will deliver workshops to other staff at Isla to bolster the planned improvement work which is supported by Richard Talleron, Power Platform.
The experience will provide Isla staff strong links with practitioners in France and will increase our capacity to deliver French well through improved pedagogy, access to better resources and materials, ICT and knowledge of modern day France. We will use Assessment is for Learning (AiFL) approaches to check ongoing progress  and to help us set next step targets with pupils so that our decisions about children’s competencies are well placed and the pace of learning is well suited to ongoing achievements.

The potential longer term benefits are positive for pupils and staff. The French immersion courses will allow the staff at Isla to work with pupils in ways which will motivate them to learn and help them to understand the importance and relevance of learning a modern language in today’s global economy. 
At Isla we are dedicated to giving our pupils the very best life chances and our long term goal is to nurture well rounded young individuals who have a positive outlook to life both in and beyond their local and national environments

The project will allow the school to now have four teachers trainied in language and methodology to embed French into everyday teaching and learning at the school.
It will help the school follow the ethos of a Curriculum for Excellence, find partners abroad to work closely with to deliver this and allow pupils to use ICT to communicate with other schools in UK and abroad.
The project will  improve the competencies of the staff members by assisting them to acquire and learn new vocabulary, improve and develop new teaching practices and gain confidence and competence at delivering French within a Curriculum for Excellence. It will enhance understanding, awareness and appreciation of the culture of modern France.
The immersion training offers opportunities to develop new teaching methods and tools. It will develop the confidence of the participants to establish formal links with French schools and allow children from Scotland and France to develop friendships, and understand similarities and differences in school life and their wider culture.
The staff members identified have demonstrated passion for integrating French into their teaching through participation in the  Scottish Government 1 + 2 initiative and other modern language CPD activities. The training offers opportunities for the participants to improve their language competency and enhance teaching skills to deliver engaging French lessons to primary school aged children.
This will be achieved through assisting the participants to:
• Improve methodological expertise in the teaching of French to young learners
• Acquire materials and ideas suitable for the teaching of the French at primary level
• Develop cultural awareness and understanding of contemporary France including the education system 
• Improve competence and performance in speaking and teaching French 
• Use relevant, engaging internet and other ICT resources in their class.
The course will provide the participants with greater confidence and ability to teach Modern Foreign Languages and a greater cultural awareness which can be transferred to pupils. This will allow staff to teach French in a more ad hoc way, several times a week rather than just 1 session per week.
All new resources will be placed on a shared drive within the school, to help learning and teaching throughout the school.
The activities will raise awareness of the importance of languages and Europe within the school to pupils, staff, parents and other stakeholders.
Social media, brochures, blogs, press articles in the local newspapers, exhibitions and open events in school will all be used to promote greater awareness of French language learning in the school. Results of the training will have already been communicated to colleagues through presentations and/or workshops at staff training events.
These will impact: 
• Locally –  on staff, pupils and parents.
• Regionally – by transfer of skills within cluster groups
• Nationally – developing the ability to contribute to national language events
• European level – increasing European links with Primary/ Secondary schools

As a result of the recent 1+2 government language policy and the commitment from Angus Council to implement the long term strategy, Whitehills Primary School require their staff members to up-level their language skills. At present, following the introduction of the PLPlatform, we are teaching French throughout all stages of the school. As a result, pupils will be learning French from Nursery to Primary 7 and progressing further with their spoken language skills and vocabulary knowledge than ever before. This requires the need for more skilled, knowledgeable,competent and trained staff members to implement this long term strategy effectively. Spanish has also been identified as our third language and is planned to be taught from summer 2017. Presently, there are no Spanish speaking staff members at Whitehills Primary School and this identified as a development need. The upper stages (P5-P7) require a trained and knowledgeable staff member to help plan and cascade learning and teaching opportunities. 
  The opportunity to attend these courses will enable our school to continue to create close ties to both local and international schools and facilitate networking opportunities between native French and Spanish teachers and ourselves. We aim to achieve this goal through use of E-twinning. The school has currently been working alongside our local language staff tutor to help set up links with primary schools in France and this will be similar to the links created with schools in Spain. Through the immersion experience, staff members will have a deeper and broader understanding of the cultures in both countries, which in turn can be passed on to the pupils in our school. This will develop their curiosity and appreciation of what are the similarities between France / Spain and Scotland. 
  Following attendance on the immersion courses, training CPD events will be held both within our school as well as the opportunity to share and cascade the learning with other colleagues within the area. Parents will benefit as pupils will share their learning through close home-school links in addition to on-going class assemblies, open afternoons and parents evenings. Quality resources can be made more accessible through being placed within a shared staff common area. Continued correspondence with other course participants will further develop and sustain the ongoing progression with staff development.

‘Youth Vibes for Europe’ is a multilateral youth exchange between six countries (Italy, Cyprus, FYROM, Ireland, UK and Greece). Growing out of an idea initially formed during an international seminar on youth employment, the project centres on young people developing a healthy leisure time both physically, mentally and in terms of active citizenship as part of an alternative use of their free time.  Participation of young people in making decisions about their own lives is a key element of the project.  Key objectives include exposing our young people to new experiences and opportunities, learning about Europe, engaging in informal learning as a key element of youth work, to develop interpersonal and life skills,  and learn how to be peer leaders and impact our organisations positively.  
There are young people participating who come from a range of backgrounds.  The young people have fewer social and economic opportunities and this project is a real way for them to devleop their skills and atticitued, both in terms of personal development, active citizenship and employability.  Activitites will include participating in physical leisure time activities, programmes to develop mindfulness and resilience and the participation in a youth leadership programme.  Methodologies will include group work, self directed learning, multimedia activiteis and planning and participation in porgrammme development.  The project will result in young people who have a greater understanding of themelves and of other young people from Europe, will result in more confident and socially aware young people who have changing attitudes about the opportunites and options available to them, and will result in young people who are more positive about their future and what they can do to influence it.  It will also impact on the participating organisations who will learn more about participation, policy making and the benefits of international work as a key component to our youth work practice.  
The Youth Exchange will take part between 25/04/2018 and 01/05/2018 in Florina, Greece, Region of Western Macedonia.

Youth Vibes for Europe είναι μία πολυμερής ανταλλαγή νέων μεταξύ έξι χωρών (Ιταλία, Κύπρος, ΠΓΔΜ, Ιρλανδία, Ηνωμένο Βασίλειο και Ελλάδα). Αποτελεί την εξέλιξη μιας ιδέας που αναπτύχθηκε κατά την διάρκεια ενός διεθνούς σεμιναρίου και επικεντρώνεται στους νέους και στην δημιουργία ενός υγιούς τρόπου ζωής, ψυχικά όσο και σωματικά και με αναφορά ενεργή συμμετοχή προκειμένου να περνούν εναλλακτικά μακριά από νόθες μορφές ψυχαγωγίας τον ελεύθερο τους χρόνο.
Η συμμετοχή των νέων συμβάλει στην δυνατότητα να αποφασίζουν μόνοι τους για το μέλλον τους και τις ζωές τους και αυτό αποτελεί το βασικό στοιχείο του προγράμματος. Τα βασικά χαρακτηριστικά περιλαμβάνουν την επαφή των νέων με καινούριες εμπειρίες και ευκαιρίες, την μάθηση σχετικά με την Ευρώπη, την επαφή με την μη τυπική μάθηση ως βασικό στοιχείο για το youth work, την ανάπτυξη προσωπικών δεξιοτήτων και πως να είναι επικεφαλής- ηγέτες και να αναλαμβάνουν ενεργό ρόλο στους οργανισμούς τους. Υπάρχουν νέοι που προέρχονται από διάφορα επίπεδα και διάφορα κοινωνικά στρώματα. Οι νέοι που συμμετέχουν έχουν λιγότερες κοινωνικές και οικονομικές δυνατότητες και αυτό το πρόγραμμα πραγματικά δίνει την δυνατότητα να αναπτύξουν αυτές τις ικανότητες και να έχουν περισσότερες ευκαιρίες προσωπικής εξέλιξης, ενεργούς συμμετοχής και εργασίας. Οι δραστηριότητες περιλαμβάνουν την συμμετοχή σε σωματικές δραστηριότητες, δραστηριότητες κριτικής σκέψης και "ακόνισμα" του μυαλού και συμμετοχή στο νεανικό πρόγραμμα ηγεσίας. H μεθοδολογία θα περιλαμβάνει την ομαδική εργασία, την μάθηση, τη δραστηριότητα πολυμέσων, τον προγραμματισμό και τη συμμετοχή στην ανάπτυξη προγραμμάτων. Το πρόγραμμα θα οδηγήσει τους νέους να κατανοήσουν  περισσότερα για τον εαυτό τους και για άλλους νέους από την Ευρώπη, θα οδηγήσει τους νέους να έχουν περισσότερη εμπιστοσύνη και κοινωνική ευαισθησία και να διαθέτουν κριτική στάση όσον αφορά τις ευκαιρίες και τις επιλογές που έχουν στη διάθεσή τους. Σημαντικός θα είναι και ο αντίκτυπος στους συμμετέχοντες οργανισμούς, οι οποίοι θα μάθουν περισσότερα σχετικά με τη συμμετοχή, τη χάραξη πολιτικής και τα οφέλη της διεθνούς εργασίας ως βασικό στοιχείο της έμπρακτης συμμετοχής των νέων μελών.
Η ανταλλαγή νέων θα πραγματοποιηθεί από στις 25/04/2018 έως και  01/05/2018 στη Φλώρινα, Ελλάδα, Περιφέρειας Δυτικής Μακεδονίας.
